wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement News Roundup 10/16/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

Are You Really Engaging Your People?

It’s a challenge for companies to balance between engaging employees for the employees’ benefit and engaging them for the benefit of the organization. Both are important, but without employees at the center of engagement strategy, it can very obviously seem disingenuous and self-serving. Employees are increasingly motivated to get involved in their organization for the benefit of their own personal and professional goals’companies can use that employee self-motivation to make it very clear as to what’s in it for the employee. Creating and communicating a balance between personal and organizational goals and outcomes as it relates to engagement results is key to getting all parties on board.

CSR Wins Customers And Sells Products

A recent Nielsen survey found that 66% of surveyed consumers are willing to pay more for products and services that come from companies that are committed to corporate social responsibility (CSR). Consumers increasingly want natural products that provide them with health and wellness benefits from companies they trust. Main take away: as consumer values and expectations evolve, companies have to find new, responsible ways to satisfy their customers’ needs in order to stay competitive.

How Do Employees Really Feel About Their Companies?

One of a company’s biggest challenges is retaining top employees. The author explains that the first step in solving this issue is to understand what employees currently think about their company and its initiatives. The latest sentiment-analysis tools allow organizations to gauge employee perspective on everything from diversity efforts to management progression opportunities. Companies such as Intel Corp., Twitter Inc., and IBM Corp are increasingly implementing software to better capture their employees’ thoughts, concerns and emotions. By collecting trend data, companies can make improvements and address potential issues to improve employee feelings towards their company and overall, increase retention.

Hunters or Gatherers? How to Build a Welcoming Work Environment for Millennial Hires

The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts by 2030 over 75% of the working population will be Millennials. The author explains how important it is becoming for companies to have a strategy in place that will attract and engage this growing population. He provides insight into his own strategy, which includes nurturing personas such as hunters who are motivated by challenge and gatherers who are motivated by praise and connection to others. He stresses that while both are necessary and complement each other, it’s important for organizations to effectively satisfy each personality.

Is HR Disconnected? Here’s How HR Can Reconnect And Embrace The Future

While many HR professionals are focusing efforts on optimizing employee engagement and building a strong corporate culture, many struggle with how to link HR initiatives to real business needs. This article explains the importance of evolution within the HR field in order to meet the needs of the vastly changing workplace. The author believes technology is the answer; finding new ways to automate HR processes will allow for more innovation in workforce management and data driven analytics. Without change, HR processes risk becoming obsolete.
